Section 31’s manipulation of Starfleet officers without oversight.
Choosing a partial solution that permanently alters a people rather than allowing a plague to run its course.
ContinuityNotes: Begins the two-part arc that explains the differing appearance of Klingons between classic and later Trek eras.
Formally introduces Section 31 into Enterprise’s time period.
Expands on the relationship between Enterprise and Columbia and their crews.
ThematicNotes: The unintended consequences of tampering with genetics for military gain.
Secrecy and the corrosive effects of unaccountable intelligence agencies.
Sacrifice and compromise in medical ethics when no perfect cure exists.
BehindTheScenes: Designed to reconcile long-standing continuity questions about Klingon foreheads.
Brings back Captain Erika Hernandez and the Columbia as active partners.
Balances medical drama with cloak-and-dagger intrigue involving Section 31.

Title: Divergence
Antagonists: Spreading Klingon Augment virus
Section 31’s willingness to exploit the crisis

StorySections.Text: Enterprise suffers critical engine problems under attack from a Klingon ship; Columbia attempts a daring high-warp docking maneuver so Trip can cross between ships in open space and complete vital repairs mid-flight.

With both ships stabilized, Archer confronts Reed about his ties to Harris and Section 31. Reed is torn between his oath to Starfleet and his handler’s orders to prioritize intelligence operations over the safety of Phlox and the mission.

On the Klingon world, Phlox and Antaak struggle against time as the virus mutates. Their new treatment halts the disease but locks in altered physical traits, creating a generation of Klingons who will lack the pronounced cranial ridges of their ancestors. Some Klingons regard this as a shameful disfigurement.

Archer negotiates a tenuous agreement: Phlox’s cure will be used, and in return, the Klingons will cease their Augment experiments and hush up the Federation’s involvement. Reed rejects further directives from Harris, choosing loyalty to his captain over Section 31. The Klingon High Command vows to conceal the virus’s legacy, explaining future visual discrepancies.

With the crisis contained, Columbia departs and Trip eventually returns to Enterprise, hinting that his time away has clarified his priorities. Archer recognizes that the episode has not only reshaped Klingon history but exposed the shadows within Starfleet that he can no longer ignore.

EthicalIssues: Accepting a cure that permanently alters the genetics and appearance of millions.
Cover-ups between governments to hide controversial medical history.
Refusing unlawful or unethical orders from secret agencies within one’s own service.
ContinuityNotes: Completes the explanation for the "smooth-headed" Klingons seen in the 23rd century.
Further develops Section 31’s covert influence long before its later depictions.
Highlights Columbia’s important, if brief, partnership with Enterprise.
ThematicNotes: Loyalty versus duty when institutions act in morally gray ways.
Living with the consequences of early genetic experimentation.
Secrets buried for political stability and the cost of such decisions.
BehindTheScenes: Features one of Enterprise’s most complex space-based stunt sequences with the inter-ship transfer.
Deepens Klingon lore while nodding to long-time fan questions.
Continues Season 4’s emphasis on multi-part continuity arcs.

Title: Bound
GuestCharacters: Three Orion women assigned to Enterprise
Antagonists: Orion pheromone-based manipulation and enslavement tactics
Gendered exploitation as a tool of control

StorySections.Text: Orion privateer Harrad-Sar offers Archer a potential alliance and access to valuable mining rights, presenting three striking Orion women as "gifts" to cement their new partnership. Archer, uneasy but curious, allows them aboard under the guise of cultural exchange.

The presence of the Orion women quickly disrupts shipboard routine. Male crew members become distracted and increasingly aggressive, while some officers display uncharacteristic recklessness and insubordination. T'Pol and Hoshi, less affected, suspect a biochemical cause tied to pheromones.

As tensions rise, Harrad-Sar reveals his true goal: to place Enterprise effectively under Orion control by using the women to compromise key personnel. He boasts that even Starfleet captains can be turned into assets once their crews are chemically enthralled.

T'Pol and Trip, shielded by their unique neurochemical bond, work together to counteract the pheromone influence and regain control of the ship. They expose Harrad-Sar’s scheme and reveal that in Orion society, it is in fact the women—through their biochemical power—who hold true authority, with the apparent male leaders acting as fronts.

With Harrad-Sar’s plan thwarted, the Orion women depart, leaving Enterprise’s crew to recover from both physical aftereffects and embarrassment. Trip and T'Pol’s connection is subtly strengthened, even as they continue to struggle with what their bond means for their future.

EthicalIssues: Using involuntary biochemical manipulation to undermine free will.
Treating sentient individuals as "gifts" or property in diplomatic dealings.
Responsibility for actions taken under strong external influence.
ContinuityNotes: Expands on Orion culture, hinting that Orion women secretly dominate their society.
Connects to earlier and later portrayals of Orion slave markets and pheromone effects.
Develops the Trip–T'Pol psychic bond in a new context.
ThematicNotes: Appearance versus reality in power structures.
The dangers of underestimating cultural practices that mask exploitation.
Shared resilience forged under psychological assault.
BehindTheScenes: Offers a twist on the classic Orion "slave girl" trope by inverting the power dynamic.
Mixes humor, seduction, and suspense in a single character-driven bottle episode.
Provides more exploration of Trip and T'Pol’s unusual bond.

Title: In a Mirror, Darkly, Part I
Antagonists: The Terran Empire’s brutal hierarchy
Mirror Archer’s own ambition
Tholian manipulation in interphasic space

StorySections.Text: In an alternate "Mirror" universe, humans of the Terran Empire are expansionist and ruthless. Mirror Archer seizes an opportunity when Tholians capture an enigmatic starship from another dimension—an advanced Federation vessel from a future timeline.

Serving under Admiral Forrest on the ISS Enterprise, Mirror Archer schemes to overthrow his superior. He learns that the captured ship is the USS Defiant, a Constitution-class starship displaced from a 23rd-century Federation reality. He becomes obsessed with taking the Defiant for himself to gain ultimate power.

After fomenting a mutiny and briefly seizing control of Enterprise, Archer leads a mission into Tholian space to reach the interphasic rift where the Defiant is held. The Tholians attempt to complete a web around the stranded starship, intending to dismantle it for study.

Archer and a team board the Defiant amid volatile interphasic shifts and Tholian assaults. They marvel at the ship’s advanced technology and superior weaponry, seeing in it a means to dominate the Empire. As Tholian forces close in, Archer orders a desperate escape attempt using systems his crew barely understands.

The Defiant breaks free of the web and the rift, leaving Tholian space in ruins behind it. Mirror Archer exults at his success, unaware of the political and personal consequences his sudden leap in power will bring.

EthicalIssues: Rule by fear and assassination as normalized leadership tactics.
Looting technology from another universe for imperial domination.
Using entire crews as expendable resources in personal power grabs.
ContinuityNotes: Acts as a direct sequel to the Original Series episode "The Tholian Web."
Firmly establishes Enterprise’s version of the Mirror Universe without intersecting the prime timeline.
Introduces the idea of Terrans acquiring advanced Federation tech centuries ahead of schedule.
ThematicNotes: Ambition unrestrained by ethics or loyalty.
How access to superior technology can destabilize already-violent systems.
Mirror reflections of familiar characters, showing what they might be without moral constraints.
BehindTheScenes: Features redesigned opening credits to depict the Terran Empire’s history.
Recreates classic TOS sets and designs for the Constitution-class Defiant.
Allows cast members to explore darker, more ruthless versions of their characters.

Title: In a Mirror, Darkly, Part II
GuestCharacters: Various Terran officers aboard the Defiant
Antagonists: Mirror Archer’s escalating tyranny
Mutiny and betrayal among the Terran crew
Alien resistance to the Terran Empire

StorySections.Text: Now in command of the USS Defiant, Mirror Archer revels in the ship’s superior firepower and Federation technology. He plans to return to Terran space, crush his enemies, and seize control of the Empire.

Archer forces the ISS Enterprise to act as an escort, demonstrating the Defiant’s might by obliterating powerful foes with ease. His crew grows wary as his paranoia and megalomania increase, and he begins to see plots against him everywhere.

Exploring the Defiant’s logs, Archer learns about the prime universe’s optimistic Federation and wonders if Terrans could ever achieve such unity without domination. Meanwhile, a Gorn infiltrator sabotages systems, forcing brutal responses and heightening tensions among the Terrans.

Archer crushes the Gorn threat and prepares to present the Defiant at a major Imperial gathering as proof of his right to rule. However, his arrogance proves his undoing when Mirror Hoshi poisons him and declares herself Empress, seizing the Defiant and its advantages for her own ambitions.

As the Defiant looms over Terran space, Hoshi consolidates power, promising a new era of Terran dominance grounded in stolen Federation might. The fate of the Empire remains unknown, but the Mirror Universe stands on the verge of a dramatically altered future.

EthicalIssues: Ruling through terror, assassination, and constant betrayal.
Using a captured ship to enforce imperial control over subject worlds.
The moral void in a society that prizes survival and ambition above all else.
ContinuityNotes: Completes Enterprise’s Mirror Universe duology without crossing over to the prime crew.
Showcases Constitution-class interiors and aesthetics from a different perspective.
Provides a possible explanation for later Terran shifts hinted at in other series.
ThematicNotes: Power corrupting even those already steeped in brutality.
The instability inherent in systems built on fear and treachery.
Dark reflections of Federation ideals twisted into tools of conquest.
BehindTheScenes: Widely regarded as a nostalgic tribute to The Original Series era.
Features extensive use of recreated TOS-style bridge, corridors, and uniforms.
Gives Linda Park’s Mirror Hoshi a memorable, power-grabbing turn.

Title: Demons
Antagonists: Terra Prime, a human-supremacist xenophobic movement
John Frederick Paxton’s plan to expel aliens from the Solar System

StorySections.Text: As Earth hosts a historic conference with Vulcans, Andorians, Tellarites, and others to discuss closer interstellar cooperation, a radical group called Terra Prime works in the shadows to sabotage the talks. A mysterious infant with human and Vulcan DNA is discovered, shocking both Trip and T'Pol.

Investigating the hybrid child, Enterprise uncovers evidence that Terra Prime has infiltrated key facilities in the Sol system, including the massive Mars mining complex at Orpheus Station. Paxton, Terra Prime’s charismatic and ruthless leader, believes humanity must remain "pure" and independent of alien influence.

Paxton seizes control of Orpheus Station and a powerful planetary defense array, using it to demonstrate his reach by firing a warning shot across the lunar surface. He broadcasts a manifesto demanding the removal of all non-humans from Earth and its colonies, displaying the hybrid baby as "evidence" of alien contamination.

Archer, Trip, and T'Pol race to piece together Paxton’s methods and motives. Journalist Gannet Brooks, an old acquaintance of Mayweather, appears to be involved but is revealed to be a covert operative investigating Terra Prime from within. The episode ends with Paxton fully in control of Mars’s system defenses, preparing to use them to hold Earth’s future hostage.

Facing the most serious internal human threat since the Xindi attack, Archer vows to stop Paxton and prove that humanity’s destiny lies in cooperation with other worlds, not isolation. The hybrid infant’s existence forces Trip and T'Pol to confront both their personal connection and the way xenophobes will twist that bond.

EthicalIssues: Xenophobia and supremacist ideologies masquerading as patriotism.
Using a child—especially a hybrid infant—as propaganda in a political crusade.
Sabotaging peaceful diplomatic efforts for the sake of racial or species purity.
ContinuityNotes: Begins the two-part "Demons" / "Terra Prime" arc confronting human xenophobia before the Federation’s founding.
Highlights early political tensions that will later inform the Federation’s inclusive charter.
Develops Trip and T'Pol’s relationship through the revelation of their cloned hybrid child.
ThematicNotes: Fear of the "other" as a barrier to progress.
The tension between isolationism and interdependence in emerging interstellar politics.
How personal relationships challenge rigid ideological boundaries.
BehindTheScenes: Shifts focus from external alien threats to internal human extremism.
Uses Mars and orbital infrastructure as key settings, expanding the visual scope of Earth’s system.
Sets up the emotional and political stakes resolved in the following episode, "Terra Prime."

Title: Terra Prime
Antagonists: Terra Prime, a xenophobic human-supremacist movement
John Frederick Paxton’s plan to force all aliens out of the Sol system
The threat of the Mars verteron array being used as a weapon

StorySections.Text: From his commandeered base at Orpheus Mining Complex on Mars, John Frederick Paxton broadcasts a chilling ultimatum to Earth and the assembled interstellar delegates: unless all non-humans leave the Sol system, he will use the massive Mars verteron array to obliterate Starfleet Command. He presents the cloned human–Vulcan infant created from Trip and T'Pol’s DNA as a symbol of everything Terra Prime opposes.

Archer coordinates with Minister Nathan Samuels and Starfleet to respond without triggering panic or legitimizing Terra Prime’s ideology. Enterprise heads for Mars under tight security, while on Orpheus Station, Trip and T'Pol remain Paxton’s prisoners, trying to protect the hybrid child. Paxton, suffering from a degenerative illness treated with alien medical techniques he hypocritically despises, remains committed to his extremist vision.

Using a stealth approach, Archer leads a shuttlepod infiltration team with Reed, Phlox, and Mayweather. Sabotage nearly destroys the shuttle en route, confirming there is still a Terra Prime sympathizer within Starfleet ranks. On Mars, Archer’s team sneaks onto the complex through maintenance tunnels, while Paxton prepares the array for a demonstration strike that will prove his resolve.

Archer’s team links up with Trip, who has escaped his cell and tampered with the array’s targeting subroutines. In a fierce firefight in the control room, Paxton manages to lock in the firing sequence, but Trip’s reprogramming causes the verteron beam to miss Starfleet Command and carve a harmless trench on the lunar surface instead. Paxton is arrested, the remaining Terra Prime operatives are subdued, and the immediate threat to Earth is neutralized.

Phlox discovers that the hybrid infant—whom Trip and T'Pol name Elizabeth, after Trip’s late sister—suffers from fatal genetic instability caused by her illicit creation. Despite their efforts, she dies, leaving the pair devastated but determined not to let Terra Prime’s hatred define her legacy. On Earth, Archer delivers an impassioned speech to the delegates, arguing that humanity’s true destiny lies in partnership with other worlds, not in fear and isolation.

EthicalIssues: Using weapons of mass destruction and hostage tactics to impose a supremacist ideology.
Exploiting the existence of a genetically engineered child as propaganda.
The moral responsibility to confront extremism emerging from one’s own society.
ContinuityNotes: Completes the "Demons" / "Terra Prime" two-part story confronting human xenophobia shortly before the Federation’s founding.
Further develops Trip and T'Pol’s relationship through the tragedy of their cloned hybrid daughter.
Positions Archer as a key advocate for interstellar cooperation, foreshadowing the United Federation of Planets.
ThematicNotes: Fear of the "other" as a powerful but self-destructive political force.
The cost of progress when bigotry resists change.
Choosing hope and unity in the face of grief and loss.
BehindTheScenes: Often regarded as the "true" narrative finale of Enterprise, with the subsequent episode serving as an epilogue.
Features extensive Mars-based sets and visual effects, including nods to real-world Mars missions.
Showcases Peter Weller’s performance as Paxton, blending ideological fervor with personal hypocrisy.

Title: These Are the Voyages...
GuestCharacters: Crew of the Enterprise-D (holodeck framework, unseen)
Antagonists: Kidnappers seeking to extort Shran using his daughter as leverage
Commander Riker’s internal struggle over honesty and duty during the Pegasus cover-up
The inherent limitations of viewing real lives through a holodeck simulation

StorySections.Text: In 2370, aboard the Enterprise-D, Commander William Riker wrestles with a moral dilemma related to the classified Pegasus incident. Seeking guidance, he turns to a historical holodeck program that recreates key moments from the NX-01 Enterprise’s final mission in 2161, on the eve of the founding of the United Federation of Planets.

Riker immerses himself in the simulation, observing Archer as the NX-01 heads to Earth for decommissioning and Archer prepares a pivotal speech for the Federation Charter signing. The crew look back on ten years of exploration. Old ally Shran, long believed dead, contacts Archer, begging for help after criminals kidnap his young daughter and demand payment on Rigel X.

Despite T'Pol’s concerns about timing, Archer agrees to help Shran, seeing it as a matter of honor and friendship. Riker, taking on the role of the ship’s chef within the program, uses informal conversations with the crew—especially Trip—to better understand how they balanced loyalty, risk, and command decisions. On Rigel X, Enterprise’s away team infiltrates the kidnappers’ stronghold and frees the child.

The kidnappers track Shran’s trail to Enterprise and board the ship in a last-ditch attempt at revenge and profit. When Archer is taken hostage, Trip engineers an improvised overload of plasma conduits, sacrificing himself in an explosion that kills the intruders and saves his captain. The crew are shattered by the loss, and Archer must still face the responsibility of delivering an inspirational speech at the Federation’s birth mere days later.

Riker ends the program after watching Archer and his crew assemble for the charter signing, deciding he now has the perspective he needs to face Captain Picard with the truth about the Pegasus. The episode closes with a montage of starships Enterprise—NX-01, NCC-1701, and NCC-1701-D—accompanied by the familiar mission statement about exploring strange new worlds, tying the NX-01’s legacy to that of its successors.

EthicalIssues: Using a historical crew’s final mission as a model for personal ethical decisions.
The morality of cover-ups and classified secrets versus transparency with one’s commanding officer.
Trip Tucker’s decision to embrace a fatal tactic to save a friend and symbolically safeguard the Federation’s future.
ContinuityNotes: Serves as a coda to Enterprise and a quasi-sequel to The Next Generation episode "The Pegasus".
Depicts the decommissioning of the NX-01 and the signing of the United Federation of Planets charter in 2161.
Features holodeck recreations of the Enterprise crew, linking 22nd- and 24th-century starship legacies.
ThematicNotes: Legacy and how later generations interpret the choices of their predecessors.
Sacrifice at the threshold of a new era of unity and exploration.
The tension between historical truth and the stories told about it.
BehindTheScenes: Intended as a "valentine" to the Star Trek franchise, framing the episode as a Next Generation holodeck story.
Guest stars Jonathan Frakes and Marina Sirtis reprise their roles as Riker and Troi, with voice cameos from other Next Generation actors.
Frequently criticized by fans and cast for focusing on TNG characters and for Trip’s controversial death, even as it provides a connective epilogue to the broader franchise.
